In typical Washington fashion, regulators issued confusing rules in January 2015 which led to a slowdown in commercial real estate lending.  Why should you care?  These projects create jobs and generate economic activity.  If the rules are too confusing for banks to make the loans, the economy suffers.  Today, I introduced bipartisan legislation with Congressman David Scott to better define which types of loans must comply with the “high volatility commercial real estate” rules:   • Providing a specific, legal definition for “high value commercial real estate acquisition, development, or construction loans,” correcting an overly broad definition which currently forces many stable loans to remain in the higher-cost HVCRE category. • Restores common sense standards for the amount and type of equity required • Eliminates the all-cash requirement which currently makes it difficult for small-to-medium sized developers and entrepreneurs to compete. • Clarifies when the loan on a completed development may exit the HVCRE requirements.   This is a highly-technical bill with a direct impact on the local economy.  We continue efforts to push back against unnecessary, overly-burdensome, duplicative, and confusing regulations.

Earlier this month, The Charlotte Observer asked me to comment on a Kaiser Family Foundation analysis of the American Health Care Act.  Their article omitted key facts, such as Kaiser’s own admission of several flaws in their analysis.  In response, I submitted a Letter to the Editor to quickly summarize the missing facts.  The Charlotte Observer Editorial Board refused to publish my letter, so here it is for all to see:   "And now, the rest of the story.  Regular readers will not be surprised to learn recent Charlotte Observer coverage of a Kaiser Family Foundation analysis of health care reform left out key facts.  In their own report, Kaiser admits their analysis doesn’t account for changes we made to allow larger tax credits for people over 50 and doesn’t account for flexibility we give states to make insurance more affordable within their markets.
